channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-17132] Cleanup deprecated code for WAL
item.description: There are some WAL related code which are marked as deprecated since branch-1(For example the SequenceFileLogWriter). Let's remove it in 2.0 to keep the code clean.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Remove HLogKey and SequenceFile related code in WAL.

+1 overall

This message was automatically generated.
Skimmed. +1. This is excellent cleanup. Thanks Duo Zhang
Sigh, I had the same patches at HBASE-16473. Let me review these instead since this is already rebased.

Great, the patch is a almost identical to https://github.com/enis/hbase/commit/257d04d37c3ddbfd81ea0585217dbe4be8ab0b62 (HBASE-16475) + https://github.com/enis/hbase/commit/57e479d60c71a0e87e8b8b82f756bb8b4cf1e2c3 (HBASE-16476). One difference is Writer.getLength() or WAL.getFileLength() in my patch. But this patch should be good to commit. I'll close those as duplicates after.

In HbaseObjectWritableFor96Migration we still have to increment the code++ otherwise we won't be able to read following entries since they will be off by one written from older code bases.
See:
https://github.com/enis/hbase/commit/57e479d60c71a0e87e8b8b82f756bb8b4cf1e2c3#diff-a20cbff2a97f4a66504bc6e316d66da9R232

WALSplitter.getReader() still throws CorruptedLogFileException. Why do we need this change? 


-      try {

-        in = getReader(logfile, skipErrors, reporter);

-      } catch (CorruptedLogFileException e) {

-        LOG.warn("Could not get reader, corrupted log file " + logPath, e);

-        ZKSplitLog.markCorrupted(rootDir, logfile.getPath().getName(), fs);

-        isCorrupted = true;

-      }

+      in = getReader(logfile, skipErrors, reporter);

You can remove TestDefaultWALProviderWithHLogKey.java altogether, otherwise we will run the same test twice.

We were reading the PB WAL magic twice before? It seems to be the case where the WALFactory opens the stream first, then the actual PBLogReader opens the stream again. If that is the case, then this change is good: 


-            boolean isPbWal =

-                (stream.read(magic) == magic.length)

-                    && Arrays.equals(magic, ProtobufLogReader.PB_WAL_MAGIC);

-            reader = isPbWal ? new ProtobufLogReader() : new SequenceFileLogReader();

Purge HbaseObjectWritableFor96Migration too.

Agreed, unfortunately, there is still a few Writables after all this time. I think we do not auto-update the data in the ACL table (see https://github.com/enis/hbase/commit/57e479d60c71a0e87e8b8b82f756bb8b4cf1e2c3#diff-fc4f00c92f05000f9e67dcb99dd268edR613)
We should open a bug to track these for 2.0.

WALSplitter.getReader() still throws CorruptedLogFileException. Why do we need this change?

There is a catch CorruptedLogFileException block below where we use BaseCoordinatedStateManager to handle the failure. I think this is the right way as we should depend on zk directly in WALSplitter?. And for some UTs we do not have a BaseCoordinatedStateManager so I add this


381	        // Some tests pass in a csm of null.

382	        this.csm.getSplitLogWorkerCoordination().markCorrupted(rootDir,

383	          logfile.getPath().getName(), fs);

384	      } else {

385	        // for tests only

386	        ZKSplitLog.markCorrupted(rootDir, logfile.getPath().getName(), fs);

387	      }

Purge HbaseObjectWritableFor96Migration too.

As Enis Soztutar said, we still use this class to read/write data for ACL(mainly Permission). For now maybe I could move the related code directly into the AccessControlList class and remove HbaseObjectWritableFor96Migration.

Thanks.

Add a readWritablePermissions in AccessControlList to read the old permissions and move HbaseObjectWritableFor96Migration to src/test.

Also remove TestDefaultWALProviderWithHLogKey as Enis Soztutar suggested.

We were reading the PB WAL magic twice before? It seems to be the case where the WALFactory opens the stream first, then the actual PBLogReader opens the stream again.

The PBLogReader will just use the stream passed in if it is not null without opening a new one in the init method. And I think we could do a refactoring later to remove the parameter as now we always pass null. It is not straight-forward so I do not modify it in this patch.

Thanks.

+1 overall

Will commit the v1 patch later if no objections.

Thanks.

Pushed to master.

Thanks stack and Enis Soztutar for reviewing.

SUCCESS: Integrated in Jenkins build HBase-Trunk_matrix #1999 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-Trunk_matrix/1999/)

There is a catch CorruptedLogFileException block below where we use BaseCoordinatedStateManager to handle the failure. I think this is the right way as we should depend on zk directly in WALSplitter?

I thought the exception semantics are changed. If not, it is fine.

Theoretically it is changed but actually it is not for now. The old logic ignore the BaseCoordinatedStateManager and always use zk which is wrong I think. But the only BaseCoordinatedStateManager is zk based for now so they are the same in fact.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Remove HLogKey and related classes and methods. Remove SequenceFile based log reader and writer. WALObserver and RegionObserver are changed so this is an incompatible change.
